Title: Username Format Validation for Email Address Structure
Description:
Validates that the login form correctly accepts properly formatted email
addresses as usernames and rejects malformed email formats. This test
ensures that email validation rules are properly enforced to prevent
invalid email submissions while allowing legitimate email-based logins.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment standardized: Supported browser (Chrome,
    Firefox, Safari, Edge) with desktop resolution 1920x1080 at 100%
    zoom
2.  Stable and active internet connection available
3.  No interfering browser extensions or JavaScript errors
4.  Login page is accessible and loaded successfully
5.  Email validation rules are configured and active in the system
6.  System has predefined email format requirements (e.g., must contain
    @ symbol, valid domain structure)
Steps: Navigate to the login page and observe the username input field
Expected Result:
Login page loads successfully with username and password input fields
visible and ready for input

Steps:
Enter a properly formatted email address (e.g., 'user@example.com') in
the username field
Expected Result:
Email address is accepted in the username field without validation
errors

Steps: Enter a valid password in the password field and click the login button
Expected Result:
Form proceeds to credential validation without rejecting the email
format

Steps:
Enter a malformed email address (e.g., 'userexample.com' - missing @
symbol) in the username field
Expected Result:
Email validation error is displayed indicating invalid email format
requirement

Steps:
Enter another malformed email format (e.g., 'user@.com' - missing domain
name) and attempt to proceed
Expected Result:
Form rejects the input with appropriate email format validation error
message

Steps:
Enter a malformed email with invalid domain structure (e.g.,
'user@example' - missing TLD) in the username field
Expected Result: System displays email format validation error preventing form submission

Steps:
Enter a valid email format that matches system requirements (e.g.,
'testuser@domain.com') and verify acceptance
Expected Result:
Email is accepted by the form and passes validation checks, allowing
progression to next step

Title: Successful Authentication with Valid Username and Password
Description:
Validates that users can successfully authenticate using correct
username and password credentials, resulting in session creation and
redirection to the authenticated dashboard. This test ensures the core
authentication flow works correctly with valid credentials and
establishes proper user session state.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser is open and at supported version (Chrome, Firefox, Safari,
    or Edge)
2.  Screen resolution is set to 1920x1080 or higher
3.  Browser zoom level is set to 100%
4.  Stable and active internet connection is available
5.  No browser extensions or JavaScript errors are interfering with the
    application
6.  Application login page is accessible and fully loaded
7.  User account with valid credentials exists in the system database
    (example: username='testuser' and corresponding password is set)
8.  User is not already authenticated/logged in (no active session
    exists)
9.  Browser cookies and localStorage are enabled and functional
10. Application is not in maintenance mode or experiencing technical
    issues
Steps: Navigate to the application login page URL
Expected Result:
Login page is displayed successfully with login form containing
username/email field, password field, and login button

Steps:
Enter valid username in the username/email input field (example:
'testuser')
Expected Result:
Username is entered in the field without any validation errors; field
displays the entered text

Steps:
Enter valid password in the password input field (example:
'ValidPassword123')
Expected Result:
Password is entered in the field; field masks the input with
dots/asterisks for security; no validation errors appear

Steps: Click the Login button
Expected Result:
Login button is clicked and becomes briefly disabled/shows loading state
to prevent duplicate submissions

Steps: System validates credentials against user database
Expected Result:
Credential validation completes successfully; system confirms username
exists and password matches stored hashed value

Steps: System generates secure session token and establishes user session
Expected Result:
Session token is created and stored securely; session state is
initialized with authenticated user information

Steps: System redirects user to authenticated dashboard/home page
Expected Result:
User is successfully redirected to the authenticated dashboard or home
page; URL changes to post-login destination (example: '/dashboard' or
'/home')

Steps: Verify authenticated session persists across page navigations
Expected Result:
Session token/cookie is maintained; user can navigate to different pages
within the application while remaining authenticated

Steps: Verify user information is correctly loaded on the authenticated page
Expected Result:
User-specific information is displayed on dashboard (example: username
in header, user preferences, personalized content); no error messages
appear

Steps: Verify browser storage contains session information (if applicable)
Expected Result:
Session token or authentication information is securely stored in
httpOnly cookies or encrypted client-side storage; sensitive credentials
are not exposed in localStorage

Title: Authentication Rejection with Invalid Username
Description:
Validates that login attempts with non-existent or incorrect usernames
are properly rejected without revealing whether the username exists in
the system. This test ensures unauthorized users cannot gain access
through username guessing and that error messages maintain security by
not disclosing user account information.
Preconditions:
1.  Application is deployed and accessible via supported browsers
    (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge)
2.  Browser is set to desktop resolution 1920x1080 with 100% zoom level
3.  Internet connection is stable and active
4.  No interfering browser extensions or JavaScript errors are present
5.  HTTPS/TLS encryption is enabled for all communications
6.  User database is populated with known valid usernames and email
    addresses
7.  Login page is fully loaded and functional
8.  Session storage and cookies are enabled in the browser
9.  Application is not in maintenance or degraded mode
10. Password hashing mechanism (bcrypt, PBKDF2, or similar) is
    operational
Steps: Navigate to the login page and wait for it to fully load
Expected Result:
Login page is displayed with username/email input field, password input
field, and submit button

Steps:
Enter a non-existent username (e.g., 'invaliduser123') in the username
field
Expected Result: Username is entered in the field and displayed as typed

Steps:
Enter a valid password format (e.g., 'ValidPass123!') in the password
field
Expected Result: Password is entered in the field and masked/hidden for security

Steps: Click the login/submit button
Expected Result:
Form submission is initiated and processed by the backend authentication
service

Steps:
Wait for the authentication service to validate credentials against the
user database
Expected Result: Authentication process completes and returns a rejection response

Steps: Observe the error message displayed on the login page
Expected Result:
A generic error message is displayed (e.g., 'Invalid credentials' or
'Login failed') without revealing whether the username exists or is
invalid

Steps:
Verify that the user is still on the login page and no redirect has
occurred
Expected Result:
User remains on the login page; no session has been created and no
redirect to dashboard/home page occurs

Steps:
Check browser console and network requests to confirm HTTPS usage and no
credential exposure
Expected Result:
All requests use HTTPS/TLS encryption; no plaintext credentials are
visible in logs or network traffic

Steps:
Attempt to access a protected resource (e.g., dashboard URL) without
logging in
Expected Result:
User is redirected back to login page; access to protected resources is
denied

Title: Generic Error Message Display for Invalid Username
Description:
Validates that error messages for invalid usernames provide generic
feedback without revealing whether the username exists in the system.
This test ensures that error messages like 'Invalid credentials' are
displayed instead of 'Username not found', preventing username
enumeration attacks.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment is standardized: supported browser (Chrome,
    Firefox, Safari, or Edge) is open and active
2.  System is accessible and running with authentication functionality
    enabled
3.  HTTPS connection is active and verified
4.  Test data setup: At least one valid user account exists in the
    system with known credentials (e.g., username 'testuser1' and
    password 'ValidPassword123')
5.  Test account for invalid username testing is prepared: username does
    not exist in the system (e.g., 'nonexistentuser123')
6.  Login page is displayed and ready for input
7.  Browser cache and cookies are cleared to ensure fresh session state
8.  JavaScript is enabled in the browser
Steps: Navigate to the login page and verify the page loads successfully
Expected Result:
Login page is displayed with username/email input field, password input
field, and login button visible

Steps:
Enter an invalid username (example: 'nonexistentuser123') that does not
exist in the system
Expected Result:
Invalid username is entered in the username field without any immediate
validation error

Steps:
Enter any password value (example: 'SomePassword123') in the password
field
Expected Result: Password is entered in the password field

Steps: Click the 'Login' or 'Sign In' button to submit the form
Expected Result: Form is submitted and system processes the authentication request

Steps: Wait for system response and observe the error message displayed
Expected Result:
A generic error message is displayed (example: 'Invalid credentials' or
'Authentication failed') without revealing whether the username exists
or not

Steps:
Verify the error message does NOT contain phrases such as 'Username not
found', 'User does not exist', or any indication that the username is
invalid
Expected Result:
Error message is generic and does not distinguish between invalid
username and invalid password scenarios

Steps:
Verify that the user remains on the login page and is not redirected to
the dashboard or home page
Expected Result: User is still on the login page; no authentication session is created

Steps:
Verify that the error message is visible to the user in an appropriate
location (example: below the form or in an error banner)
Expected Result:
Error message is displayed clearly and in a user-visible area without
requiring additional clicks or scrolling

Title: Password Complexity Requirements Enforcement
Description:
Tests that the login form enforces defined password complexity
requirements including minimum length, character variety, and special
character inclusion. This validation ensures that only passwords meeting
security standards are accepted during login attempts.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment standardized: Supported browser (Chrome,
    Firefox, Safari, Edge) with desktop resolution 1920x1080 at 100%
    zoom
2.  Stable and active internet connection available
3.  No interfering browser extensions or JavaScript errors
4.  Login page is accessible and loaded successfully
5.  Password complexity requirements are defined and enforced in the
    system (e.g., minimum length, character variety, special characters)
6.  System configuration specifies exact complexity rules (e.g., minimum
    8 characters, at least 1 uppercase, 1 lowercase, 1 digit, 1 special
    character)
Steps: Navigate to the login page and locate the password input field
Expected Result:
Login page loads successfully with password input field visible and
accessible

Steps:
Enter a password that does not meet minimum length requirements (e.g.,
password shorter than the defined minimum) in the password field
Expected Result:
System displays password complexity validation error indicating minimum
length requirement is not met

Steps:
Enter a password that meets minimum length but lacks required character
variety (e.g., only lowercase letters) in the password field
Expected Result:
Form displays validation error indicating that multiple character types
(uppercase, lowercase, digits, special characters) are required

Steps:
Enter a password that meets length and character variety requirements
but lacks special characters (if required by policy) in the password
field
Expected Result:
System displays validation error indicating that special character
inclusion is required

Steps:
Enter a password that meets all complexity requirements (e.g., contains
uppercase, lowercase, digits, and special characters at defined minimum
length) in the password field
Expected Result:
Password passes all complexity validation checks and is accepted by the
form

Steps:
Attempt to submit the login form with the valid complex password and a
valid username
Expected Result:
Form accepts the password meeting all complexity requirements and
proceeds to credential validation

Title: Successful Authentication with Valid Email Address and Password
Description:
Verifies that users can authenticate successfully using their email
address instead of username along with the correct password. This test
confirms that the system supports both username and email as valid login
identifiers and properly processes email-based authentication.
Preconditions:
1.  User has a valid registered account with an email address and
    password
2.  Email verification is complete (if required by the system)
3.  Account is in active status and not locked or suspended
4.  Browser is set to a supported version (Chrome, Firefox, Safari,
    Edge)
5.  Browser resolution is set to 1920x1080 with 100% zoom level
6.  Stable and active internet connection is available
7.  No interfering browser extensions or JavaScript errors are present
8.  Login page is accessible and fully loaded
9.  Cookies are enabled in the browser
Steps: Navigate to the login page
Expected Result:
Login page is displayed with email/username field, password field, and
submit button visible

Steps: Enter the valid email address in the email/username field
Expected Result:
Email address is entered correctly in the input field without any
validation errors

Steps: Enter the correct password in the password field
Expected Result:
Password is entered in the field (displayed as masked characters for
security)

Steps: Click the 'Login' or 'Submit' button
Expected Result: Login request is processed and sent to the server

Steps: Wait for server authentication to complete
Expected Result:
Server validates the email address and password against the user
database

Steps: Observe the authentication response
Expected Result:
Authentication is successful; user is authenticated and ready for
redirection

Title: Empty Username Field Validation and Error Handling
Description:
Verifies that the login form properly validates and rejects login
attempts with empty username fields, displaying appropriate validation
error messages. This test ensures that required field validation is
enforced before credential processing.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment standardized: Supported browser (Chrome,
    Firefox, Safari, Edge) with desktop resolution 1920x1080 at 100%
    zoom
2.  Stable and active internet connection available
3.  No interfering browser extensions or JavaScript errors
4.  Login page is accessible and loaded successfully
5.  Username field is designated as a required field in the form
    validation rules
6.  Clear error messages are configured for empty field validation
Steps: Navigate to the login page and observe all form fields
Expected Result:
Login page loads successfully with username and password input fields
visible and empty

Steps: Leave the username field empty and click the login submit button
Expected Result: Form validation is triggered and prevents form submission

Steps: Observe the error message displayed for the empty username field
Expected Result:
Clear validation error message is displayed indicating that username
field is required (e.g., 'Username is required' or similar message)

Steps:
Verify that the username field is highlighted or visually marked to
indicate the validation error
Expected Result:
Username input field is visually highlighted (e.g., red border or
background) to draw attention to the validation error

Steps: Enter a valid username or email in the username field
Expected Result: Error message disappears and the field validation error is cleared

Steps: Verify that the form can now proceed with a valid username entered
Expected Result:
With valid username populated, the form no longer displays empty field
validation error

Title: Authentication Rejection with Invalid Email Address
Description:
Verifies that login attempts using non-existent or incorrect email
addresses are rejected with secure error messaging that does not reveal
whether the email is registered in the system. This test protects
against email enumeration attacks while providing appropriate user
feedback.
Preconditions:
1.  Application is deployed and accessible via supported browsers
    (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge)
2.  Browser is set to desktop resolution 1920x1080 with 100% zoom level
3.  Internet connection is stable and active
4.  No interfering browser extensions or JavaScript errors are present
5.  HTTPS/TLS encryption is enabled for secure credential transmission
6.  User database is populated with known valid email addresses
7.  Login page is fully loaded and functional
8.  Email validation mechanism is implemented and operational
9.  Session storage and cookies are enabled in the browser
10. Application is not in maintenance or degraded mode
Steps: Navigate to the login page and ensure it is fully loaded
Expected Result:
Login page is displayed with username/email input field, password input
field, and submit button

Steps:
Enter a non-existent email address (e.g., 'nonexistent@example.com') in
the email field
Expected Result: Email address is entered in the field and displayed as typed

Steps:
Enter a valid password format (e.g., 'ValidPass123!') in the password
field
Expected Result: Password is entered and masked/hidden for security

Steps: Click the login/submit button
Expected Result: Form submission is initiated and processed by the authentication service

Steps:
Wait for the authentication service to validate the email and
credentials against the user database
Expected Result: Authentication process completes and returns a rejection response

Steps: Observe the error message displayed on the login page
Expected Result:
A generic error message is displayed (e.g., 'Invalid credentials' or
'Login failed') without indicating whether the email address is or is
not registered

Steps: Verify that no session token or authenticated session has been created
Expected Result:
User remains on the login page; no authentication cookies or session
tokens are present in browser storage

Steps:
Confirm that the error message does not differentiate between 'email not
found' and 'incorrect password' scenarios
Expected Result:
Error message is consistent and generic, preventing email enumeration
attacks

Steps: Attempt to access protected resources via direct URL navigation
Expected Result:
User is redirected to login page; access is denied and no authenticated
session exists

Title: Generic Error Message Display for Invalid Password
Description:
Tests that error messages for incorrect passwords do not distinguish
between wrong password and invalid username scenarios. This ensures that
attackers cannot determine valid usernames by analyzing different error
message patterns for password failures.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment is standardized: supported browser (Chrome,
    Firefox, Safari, or Edge) is open and active
2.  System is accessible and running with authentication functionality
    enabled
3.  HTTPS connection is active and verified
4.  Test data setup: At least one valid user account exists in the
    system with known credentials (example: username 'testuser1' and
    password 'ValidPassword123')
5.  Invalid password test data is prepared (example:
    'IncorrectPassword456')
6.  Login page is displayed and ready for input
7.  Browser cache and cookies are cleared to ensure fresh session state
8.  JavaScript is enabled in the browser
Steps: Navigate to the login page and verify the page loads successfully
Expected Result:
Login page is displayed with username/email input field, password input
field, and login button visible

Steps: Enter a valid username (example: 'testuser1') that exists in the system
Expected Result: Valid username is entered in the username field

Steps:
Enter an incorrect/invalid password (example: 'IncorrectPassword456')
that does not match the account
Expected Result: Incorrect password is entered in the password field

Steps: Click the 'Login' or 'Sign In' button to submit the form
Expected Result: Form is submitted and system processes the authentication request

Steps: Wait for system response and observe the error message displayed
Expected Result:
A generic error message is displayed (example: 'Invalid credentials' or
'Authentication failed')

Steps:
Verify that the error message is identical or indistinguishable from the
error message shown when an invalid username is used
Expected Result:
Error message does not indicate specifically that the password is
incorrect; message is generic and consistent with invalid username
scenarios

Steps:
Verify the error message does NOT contain phrases such as 'Password is
incorrect', 'Wrong password', 'Password mismatch', or similar
password-specific indicators
Expected Result:
Error message remains generic without revealing password validation
details

Steps:
Verify that the user remains on the login page and is not redirected to
the dashboard or home page
Expected Result: User is still on the login page; no authentication session is created

Steps:
Compare the error message structure and format with the error message
from a test case with invalid username to confirm consistency
Expected Result:
Error message format and structure are identical to or indistinguishable
from invalid username error message

Title: Session Creation and Persistence After Successful Login
Description:
Confirms that a secure session token is generated upon successful
authentication and persists across page navigations within the
authenticated area. This test validates that the session state is
maintained correctly and users remain logged in during their browsing
session.
Preconditions:
1.  User has a valid registered account with active status
2.  User is not currently logged in (fresh session)
3.  Browser supports session storage and cookies are enabled
4.  Session storage mechanism (server-side session store or secure token
    storage) is functional
5.  Browser is set to a supported version (Chrome, Firefox, Safari,
    Edge)
6.  Browser resolution is set to 1920x1080 with 100% zoom level
7.  Stable and active internet connection is available
8.  No interfering browser extensions are present
9.  Login page is accessible and fully loaded
Steps: Navigate to the login page
Expected Result:
Login page is displayed with email/username field, password field, and
submit button

Steps: Enter valid username/email and correct password
Expected Result: Credentials are entered in the respective input fields

Steps: Click the 'Login' or 'Submit' button
Expected Result: Credentials are submitted to the server for authentication

Steps: Wait for server to process authentication
Expected Result:
Server validates credentials and generates a secure session token upon
successful authentication

Steps: Observe session token creation
Expected Result:
Session token is created and stored securely (in browser storage or as
httpOnly cookie)

Steps: User is redirected to authenticated area
Expected Result:
User lands on the authenticated home/dashboard page with session token
active

Steps:
Navigate to a different page within the authenticated area (e.g., from
dashboard to profile page)
Expected Result:
Session token is validated on the new page; user remains logged in and
page loads with authenticated content

Steps: Refresh the current page using browser refresh button
Expected Result:
Page reloads with session token validated; user remains logged in and
content persists

Steps: Navigate back using browser back button
Expected Result: Navigation succeeds with session maintained; user remains authenticated

Title: Clear User Guidance Without Security Information Disclosure
Description:
Verifies that error messages provide helpful guidance to legitimate
users while maintaining security by not revealing sensitive system
information. This test ensures that error messages are user-friendly yet
secure, helping users troubleshoot without exposing attack vectors.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment is standardized: supported browser (Chrome,
    Firefox, Safari, or Edge) is open and active
2.  System is accessible and running with authentication functionality
    enabled
3.  HTTPS connection is active and verified
4.  Login page is displayed and ready for input
5.  Browser cache and cookies are cleared to ensure fresh session state
6.  JavaScript is enabled in the browser
7.  Test data: Invalid credentials are prepared (example: username
    'invaliduser' and password 'invalidpass')
Steps: Navigate to the login page and verify the page loads successfully
Expected Result:
Login page is displayed with username/email input field, password input
field, login button, and password recovery link (if available) visible

Steps:
Enter invalid credentials (example: username 'invaliduser' and password
'invalidpass')
Expected Result: Invalid credentials are entered in respective fields

Steps: Click the 'Login' or 'Sign In' button to submit the form
Expected Result: Form is submitted and system processes the authentication request

Steps: Wait for system response and observe the error message displayed
Expected Result:
An error message is displayed that provides generic feedback without
exposing system details

Steps:
Verify that the error message provides helpful guidance to legitimate
users (example: 'Please check your username and password and try again')
Expected Result:
Error message includes guidance that helps users understand what went
wrong without exposing security information

Steps:
Verify that if a password recovery option exists, it is mentioned or
accessible from the login page
Expected Result:
Password recovery/forgot password link or option is visible and
accessible on the login page

Steps:
Verify that the error message does NOT contain sensitive information
such as: database error messages, system file paths, internal IP
addresses, API endpoints, or framework/technology stack details
Expected Result:
Error message is clean of technical/sensitive information and presents a
user-friendly message only

Steps:
Verify that the error message is clearly readable and positioned in an
accessible location on the page
Expected Result:
Error message is visible without requiring additional scrolling or
interactions; text is readable and contrasted appropriately

Title: Authentication Rejection with Incorrect Password for Valid Username
Description:
Tests that login attempts with correct username but wrong password are
rejected without indicating that the username is valid. This ensures
that attackers cannot determine valid usernames through password
guessing attempts and maintains credential security.
Preconditions:
1.  Application is deployed and accessible via supported browsers
    (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge)
2.  Browser is set to desktop resolution 1920x1080 with 100% zoom level
3.  Internet connection is stable and active
4.  No interfering browser extensions or JavaScript errors are present
5.  HTTPS/TLS encryption is enabled for secure credential transmission
6.  A known valid username exists in the user database (e.g.,
    'testuser')
7.  Login page is fully loaded and functional
8.  Password validation and hashing mechanism is operational
9.  Session management system is operational
10. Browser cookies and session storage are enabled
Steps: Navigate to the login page and wait for it to fully load
Expected Result:
Login page is displayed with username/email input field, password input
field, and submit button

Steps: Enter a known valid username (e.g., 'testuser') in the username field
Expected Result: Username is entered in the field and displayed as typed

Steps:
Enter an incorrect password (e.g., 'WrongPassword123!') that does not
match the user's actual password in the password field
Expected Result: Password is entered and masked/hidden for security

Steps: Click the login/submit button
Expected Result: Form submission is initiated and processed by the authentication service

Steps:
Wait for the authentication service to validate credentials against the
user database
Expected Result:
Authentication process completes and returns a rejection response
because password does not match

Steps: Observe the error message displayed on the login page
Expected Result:
A generic error message is displayed (e.g., 'Invalid credentials' or
'Login failed') without revealing that the username is valid

Steps: Verify that the user is still on the login page
Expected Result: User remains on the login page; no redirect to authenticated area occurs

Steps:
Confirm that no session token has been created in browser storage or
cookies
Expected Result:
Browser cookies and session storage contain no authentication tokens or
session identifiers

Steps: Attempt to access protected resources using direct URL navigation
Expected Result:
User is redirected to login page; access is denied and authentication is
not granted

Steps:
Verify that error message is identical whether username is invalid or
password is incorrect
Expected Result:
Same generic error message is displayed in both scenarios, preventing
username enumeration attacks

Title: Empty Password Field Validation and Error Handling
Description:
Tests that the login form correctly identifies and rejects login
attempts with empty password fields, providing clear validation feedback
to users. This ensures that password requirements are enforced at the
form level before authentication processing.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment standardized: Supported browser (Chrome,
    Firefox, Safari, Edge) with desktop resolution 1920x1080 at 100%
    zoom
2.  Stable and active internet connection available
3.  No interfering browser extensions or JavaScript errors
4.  Login page is accessible and loaded successfully
5.  Password field is designated as a required field in the form
    validation rules
6.  Clear error messages are configured for empty password field
    validation
Steps: Navigate to the login page and observe the password input field
Expected Result:
Login page loads successfully with password input field visible and
empty

Steps: Enter a valid username or email in the username field
Expected Result: Username is accepted and entered in the username field

Steps: Leave the password field empty and click the login submit button
Expected Result:
Form validation is triggered and prevents form submission due to empty
password field

Steps: Observe the error message displayed for the empty password field
Expected Result:
Clear validation error message is displayed indicating that password
field is required (e.g., 'Password is required' or similar message)

Steps:
Verify that the password field is highlighted or visually marked to
indicate the validation error
Expected Result:
Password input field is visually highlighted (e.g., red border, error
icon, or background color) to indicate validation failure

Steps: Enter a valid password in the password field
Expected Result:
Error message disappears and the field validation error is cleared upon
entering password

Steps:
Verify that the form can now proceed with both valid username and
password populated
Expected Result:
With valid password entered, the form no longer displays empty password
field validation error and is ready for submission

Title: Prevention of Session Creation for Invalid Login Attempts
Description:
Confirms that no session tokens or authenticated sessions are created
when login attempts fail due to invalid credentials. This test ensures
that failed authentication does not result in any form of unauthorized
access or partial authentication state.
Preconditions:
1.  Application is deployed and accessible via supported browsers
    (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge)
2.  Browser is set to desktop resolution 1920x1080 with 100% zoom level
3.  Internet connection is stable and active
4.  No interfering browser extensions or JavaScript errors are present
5.  HTTPS/TLS encryption is enabled for all communications
6.  Session management and token generation system is operational
7.  Login page is fully loaded and functional
8.  Browser developer tools are available for session inspection
9.  Cookies and session storage are enabled in browser
10. Multiple invalid credential scenarios can be tested (invalid
    username, invalid password, invalid email, etc.)
Steps:
Open browser developer tools and navigate to the Application/Storage tab
to monitor cookies and session storage
Expected Result:
Developer tools are open and ready to monitor session tokens and
authentication-related storage

Steps: Navigate to the login page
Expected Result: Login page is fully loaded with username/email and password input fields

Steps:
Record any existing session tokens or cookies in the Application/Storage
tab (baseline)
Expected Result:
Baseline session state is documented; no authentication tokens are
present initially

Steps:
Enter invalid credentials (e.g., non-existent username 'invaliduser' and
password 'wrongpass') in the login form
Expected Result: Invalid credentials are entered in both fields

Steps: Click the login/submit button
Expected Result: Form submission is initiated and authentication is attempted

Steps:
Wait for the authentication service to process the request and return a
rejection response
Expected Result: Authentication fails and returns error response

Steps: Verify the error message is displayed on the login page
Expected Result: Generic error message is shown to the user

Steps:
Check the Application/Storage tab in developer tools for any new session
tokens, authentication cookies, or session identifiers
Expected Result:
No new authentication tokens or session cookies are created; browser
storage remains unchanged from baseline

Steps:
Inspect HTTP response headers (using Network tab) to confirm no
Set-Cookie headers or token-related headers are present
Expected Result:
Response headers contain no authentication-related cookies or session
tokens

Steps:
Attempt direct access to a protected resource (e.g., /dashboard or
/profile) without logging in
Expected Result:
Request is denied and user is redirected to login page; no
authentication state exists

Steps:
Repeat the test with different invalid credential combinations (invalid
email, correct username with wrong password, etc.)
Expected Result:
In all cases, no session tokens are created and protected resources
remain inaccessible

Title: Consistent Error Message Format Across Authentication Failures
Description:
Tests that all authentication failure scenarios display error messages
in a consistent format and structure to prevent information leakage
through message variations. This ensures that error message consistency
cannot be used to infer different types of authentication failures.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment is standardized: supported browser (Chrome,
    Firefox, Safari, or Edge) is open and active
2.  System is accessible and running with authentication functionality
    enabled
3.  HTTPS connection is active and verified
4.  Test data setup: At least one valid user account exists (example:
    username 'testuser1' with password 'ValidPassword123')
5.  Invalid username test data prepared (example: 'nonexistentuser')
6.  Invalid password test data prepared (example: 'IncorrectPassword')
7.  Empty field test data: prepared to test with empty username/password
8.  Login page is displayed and ready for input
9.  Browser cache and cookies are cleared to ensure fresh session state
10. JavaScript is enabled in the browser
Steps: Navigate to the login page and verify the page loads successfully
Expected Result: Login page is displayed with input fields and login button visible

Steps:
Test Case 1 - Invalid Username: Enter invalid username (example:
'nonexistentuser') and any password, then click Login
Expected Result: System returns an error message

Steps:
Document the exact error message format and text from the invalid
username scenario
Expected Result:
Error message is captured (example: 'Invalid credentials' format and
structure noted)

Steps: Clear the form and navigate back to login page
Expected Result: Login form is reset and ready for next test

Steps:
Test Case 2 - Invalid Password: Enter valid username (example:
'testuser1') and invalid password (example: 'IncorrectPassword'), then
click Login
Expected Result: System returns an error message

Steps:
Document the exact error message format and text from the invalid
password scenario
Expected Result: Error message is captured for comparison

Steps:
Compare the error message format, wording, and structure from both test
cases
Expected Result:
Both error messages are identical or indistinguishable in format,
wording, and structure

Steps:
Test Case 3 - Empty Username: Leave username field empty, enter any
password, then click Login
Expected Result: System returns an appropriate validation error or authentication error

Steps: Document the error message format from empty username scenario
Expected Result: Error message format is captured for comparison

Steps:
Verify that validation errors (empty fields) may have a different format
than authentication errors, but authentication-related errors all follow
the same consistent format
Expected Result:
Validation errors are distinct from authentication errors; all
authentication failure messages are consistent

Steps:
Perform multiple authentication failure scenarios and verify all follow
the same error message format and structure
Expected Result:
Consistent error message format is maintained across all authentication
failure scenarios to prevent information leakage

Title: Input Sanitization for Special Characters in Login Fields
Description:
Validates that special characters, symbols, and potentially malicious
input in username and password fields are properly sanitized without
breaking legitimate authentication. This test ensures that input
sanitization protects against injection attacks while preserving valid
special characters in credentials.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment standardized: Supported browser (Chrome,
    Firefox, Safari, Edge) with desktop resolution 1920x1080 at 100%
    zoom
2.  Stable and active internet connection available
3.  No interfering browser extensions or JavaScript errors
4.  Login page is accessible and loaded successfully
5.  Input sanitization mechanisms are configured and active in the
    system
6.  System has predefined rules for handling special characters in
    credentials (e.g., single quotes, double quotes, angle brackets,
    etc.)
7.  Database contains test user accounts with special characters in
    their credentials for validation
Steps:
Navigate to the login page and locate the username and password input
fields
Expected Result:
Login page loads successfully with both input fields visible and ready
for interaction

Steps:
Enter a username containing special characters (e.g., single quote
character like 'user@ex'ample.com' or similar) in the username field
Expected Result:
Username with special characters is accepted by the form field without
blocking input

Steps:
Enter a password containing special characters (e.g., exclamation mark,
hash, dollar sign, percentage symbol like 'Pass@123!#%') in the password
field
Expected Result:
Password with special characters is accepted in the password field and
stored properly

Steps:
Enter a username with potentially malicious input patterns (e.g., SQL
injection attempt like "' OR '1'='1") in the username field
Expected Result:
System accepts the input but applies sanitization rules; the input is
treated as literal string data, not executable code

Steps:
Click the login submit button with special characters and potentially
malicious patterns in both fields
Expected Result:
Form submission proceeds with sanitized input; special characters are
properly escaped or encoded to prevent injection attacks

Steps:
Verify that the login request is processed safely without executing any
code from the input
Expected Result:
Backend validation confirms that special characters were sanitized
properly and no code injection occurred; authentication is validated
against actual credentials

Steps:
Enter credentials with valid special characters that are part of
legitimate email or password (e.g., 'user+tag@domain.com' or
'MyPass@2024!') and attempt login
Expected Result:
Legitimate special characters in valid credentials are preserved and not
stripped, allowing proper authentication with credentials containing
valid special characters

Title: Redirection to Authenticated Dashboard After Valid Login
Description:
Verifies that users are automatically redirected to the appropriate
authenticated dashboard or home page after successful login. This test
ensures the post-authentication user experience flows correctly and
users land on the expected page.
Preconditions:
1.  User has a valid registered account with active status
2.  User is not currently logged in
3.  Browser is set to a supported version (Chrome, Firefox, Safari,
    Edge)
4.  Browser resolution is set to 1920x1080 with 100% zoom level
5.  Cookies are enabled in the browser
6.  Stable and active internet connection is available
7.  No interfering browser extensions are present
8.  Login page is accessible and fully loaded
9.  Authenticated dashboard/home page is accessible
Steps: Navigate to the login page
Expected Result:
Login page is fully loaded and displays login form with email/username
and password fields

Steps: Enter valid email/username in the email/username field
Expected Result: Valid email/username is entered without any validation errors

Steps: Enter correct password in the password field
Expected Result: Password is entered in the field (masked for security)

Steps: Click the 'Login' or 'Submit' button
Expected Result: Login request is processed; authentication begins

Steps: Wait for authentication process to complete
Expected Result: Server validates credentials successfully and prepares redirection

Steps: Observe redirection behavior
Expected Result:
User is automatically redirected to the authenticated dashboard or home
page

Steps: Verify the landing page URL and content
Expected Result:
Current URL matches the authenticated dashboard/home page URL; page
displays authenticated user content (e.g., user name, profile
information, personalized content)

Title: Case Sensitive Password Authentication Validation
Description:
Tests that password authentication correctly handles case sensitivity,
accepting only the exact password case and rejecting variations with
different capitalization. This validates that password security is
maintained through proper case-sensitive matching.
Preconditions:
1.  User has a valid registered account with a password containing mixed
    case characters (e.g., 'MyPassword123')
2.  Account is in active status and not locked
3.  Browser is set to a supported version (Chrome, Firefox, Safari,
    Edge)
4.  Browser resolution is set to 1920x1080 with 100% zoom level
5.  Cookies are enabled in the browser
6.  Stable and active internet connection is available
7.  No interfering browser extensions are present
8.  Login page is accessible and fully loaded
Steps: Navigate to the login page
Expected Result:
Login page is displayed with email/username field, password field, and
login button

Steps: Enter valid username/email
Expected Result: Valid username/email is entered in the respective field

Steps:
Enter the password with all characters in correct case (e.g.,
'MyPassword123')
Expected Result: Correct password with proper case is entered in the password field

Steps: Click the 'Login' button
Expected Result: Login request is submitted to the server

Steps: Wait for authentication to complete
Expected Result: Server validates the case-sensitive password and authentication succeeds

Steps: Observe successful authentication response
Expected Result:
User is authenticated and redirected to authenticated area; login is
successful

Steps: Return to login page and enter the same username/email
Expected Result: Username/email is entered again

Steps:
Enter password with incorrect case variation (e.g., 'mypassword123' or
'MYPASSWORD123')
Expected Result: Incorrect case password is entered in the password field

Steps: Click the 'Login' button
Expected Result: Login request is submitted with incorrect case password

Steps: Wait for authentication validation
Expected Result:
Server validates the case-sensitive password and finds mismatch;
authentication fails

Steps: Observe authentication failure response
Expected Result:
Error message is displayed indicating invalid credentials; user is not
authenticated and remains on login page

Title: Prevention of Sensitive Data Exposure in Error Responses
Description:
Validates that error messages and HTTP responses do not contain
sensitive information such as database errors, system paths, or internal
application details. This test ensures that authentication failures do
not inadvertently expose system architecture or configuration
information.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment is standardized: supported browser (Chrome,
    Firefox, Safari, or Edge) is open and active
2.  System is accessible and running with authentication functionality
    enabled
3.  HTTPS connection is active and verified
4.  Network monitoring tools (example: browser Developer Tools Network
    tab) are available for inspecting HTTP responses
5.  Test data: Invalid credentials prepared (example: username
    'invaliduser' and password 'invalidpass')
6.  Login page is displayed and ready for input
7.  Browser cache and cookies are cleared
8.  JavaScript is enabled in the browser
Steps:
Open Browser Developer Tools (F12 or right-click > Inspect) and
navigate to the Network tab
Expected Result: Network tab is open and ready to capture HTTP requests and responses

Steps: Navigate to the login page and verify the page loads successfully
Expected Result:
Login page is displayed; Network tab shows page load request without
sensitive information

Steps:
Enter invalid credentials (example: username 'invaliduser' and password
'invalidpass')
Expected Result: Invalid credentials are entered in respective fields

Steps:
Click the 'Login' or 'Sign In' button to submit the form while observing
the Network tab
Expected Result:
Authentication request is sent to the server; request appears in Network
tab

Steps:
Locate the authentication request in the Network tab and click on it to
view request/response details
Expected Result:
Request details are displayed showing method (POST), endpoint, headers,
and payload

Steps:
Verify that the HTTP response status code is appropriate (example: 401
Unauthorized or 400 Bad Request) for authentication failure
Expected Result:
Response status code indicates authentication failure without exposing
additional information

Steps:
Examine the response body/payload in the Network tab to verify it does
not contain: database error messages, SQL error details, system file
paths, stack traces, or internal API endpoint information
Expected Result:
Response body contains only the generic error message displayed to the
user; no sensitive technical information is present

Steps:
Verify that the HTML response does not contain commented-out code, debug
information, or sensitive data in meta tags or data attributes
Expected Result: HTML source is clean of debug information and sensitive data

Steps:
Check the response headers for any sensitive information such as server
type/version, internal IPs, or technology stack details
Expected Result:
Response headers do not expose sensitive server or application
information

Steps: View the rendered error message on the page
Expected Result:
Error message displayed to user matches the sanitized response and
contains no sensitive information

Steps:
Repeat the test with different invalid credential combinations to verify
consistent secure error handling across multiple authentication failures
Expected Result:
All authentication failure responses maintain consistent security
posture with no sensitive data exposure

Title: Secure Error Message Display Without Information Disclosure
Description:
Verifies that error messages for invalid credentials provide generic,
non-revealing feedback that does not distinguish between invalid
username and invalid password scenarios. This prevents attackers from
using error message differences to enumerate valid accounts.
Preconditions:
1.  Application is deployed and accessible via supported browsers
    (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge)
2.  Browser is set to desktop resolution 1920x1080 with 100% zoom level
3.  Internet connection is stable and active
4.  No interfering browser extensions or JavaScript errors are present
5.  User database is populated with known valid and invalid usernames
    and email addresses
6.  Login page is fully loaded and functional
7.  Error message rendering system is implemented and operational
8.  Session management is operational
9.  Browser console is available for monitoring error responses
10. Multiple invalid credential scenarios can be tested sequentially
Steps: Navigate to the login page and ensure it is fully loaded
Expected Result: Login page is displayed with input fields and submit button

Steps:
Open browser developer tools and navigate to the Console and Network
tabs
Expected Result: Developer tools are open to monitor error messages and network responses

Steps:
Test Scenario 1: Enter a non-existent username (e.g., 'invaliduser') and
any password (e.g., 'password123') and click login
Expected Result: Form is submitted and authentication fails

Steps:
Observe and record the error message displayed for the non-existent
username scenario
Expected Result:
Error message is displayed (e.g., 'Invalid credentials' or 'Login
failed')

Steps:
Test Scenario 2: Enter a valid username (e.g., 'testuser') and an
incorrect password (e.g., 'wrongpassword') and click login
Expected Result: Form is submitted and authentication fails due to incorrect password

Steps:
Observe and record the error message displayed for the incorrect
password scenario
Expected Result:
Error message is displayed (e.g., 'Invalid credentials' or 'Login
failed')

Steps:
Compare the error messages from Scenario 1 (invalid username) and
Scenario 2 (incorrect password)
Expected Result:
Error messages are identical or contain no distinguishing information
between the two scenarios

Steps:
Verify that the error message does not contain phrases like 'username
not found', 'user does not exist', 'password incorrect', or similar
revealing text
Expected Result:
Error message is generic and non-revealing; no information is disclosed
that could indicate which credential component is invalid

Steps:
Check the Network tab to inspect the HTTP response body and headers for
any additional information disclosure
Expected Result:
Response body and headers contain no additional details that
differentiate between invalid username and invalid password

Steps:
Test with an invalid email address (e.g., 'nonexistent@example.com') and
observe the error message
Expected Result:
Same generic error message is displayed as with invalid
username/password scenarios

Steps:
Verify that error messages are rendered securely without XSS
vulnerabilities (inspect HTML source for any unescaped user input)
Expected Result:
Error messages are properly escaped and sanitized; no XSS injection
risks are present

Title: Maximum Length Validation for Username and Password Fields
Description:
Tests that the login form enforces maximum length limits for username
and password inputs to prevent buffer overflow attacks and ensure system
stability. This validation protects against excessively long input
submissions that could compromise system security or performance.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment is standardized with a supported browser
    (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Edge) at 1920x1080 resolution with 100%
    zoom level
2.  Stable and active internet connection is available with no network
    disruptions
3.  The login page is accessible and fully loaded without JavaScript
    errors
4.  User is not currently authenticated and is viewing the login page
    for the first time in this session
5.  Browser developer tools are available for verifying input field
    maximum length attributes and form submission behavior
6.  No browser extensions or plugins are interfering with form input or
    submission
Steps: Navigate to the login page and wait for all elements to fully load
Expected Result:
Login page is displayed with username and password input fields visible
and ready for interaction

Steps:
Inspect the username input field to identify the maximum length
attribute (e.g., maxlength='50' as an example)
Expected Result:
Maximum length attribute is identified for the username field; note this
value for validation purposes

Steps:
Enter a string that exceeds the maximum length limit by 20 characters
(for example, if max is 50 characters, enter 70 characters) in the
username field
Expected Result:
The username field either rejects input beyond the maximum length limit
or automatically truncates to the maximum allowed length without
allowing overflow

Steps:
Inspect the password input field to identify the maximum length
attribute
Expected Result:
Maximum length attribute is identified for the password field; note this
value for validation purposes

Steps:
Enter a string that exceeds the maximum length limit by 20 characters in
the password field
Expected Result:
The password field either rejects input beyond the maximum length limit
or automatically truncates to the maximum allowed length without
allowing overflow

Steps:
Attempt to submit the login form with username and password both at
their maximum allowed length
Expected Result:
Form submission is processed normally without errors, demonstrating that
maximum length limits do not prevent legitimate submissions

Steps:
Verify in browser developer tools or network inspector that the
submitted payload contains only the truncated/limited values, not the
excess characters
Expected Result:
Submitted credentials in the request payload contain only characters
within the maximum length limit, confirming no buffer overflow risk

Steps:
Test with special characters at maximum length boundaries (for example,
entering special characters like '@', '#', '$' up to the limit)
Expected Result:
Special characters are handled correctly within the maximum length
constraints without causing validation errors or system instability

Title: Unicode and International Character Support in Login Fields
Description:
Verifies that the login form correctly handles Unicode characters and
international character sets in usernames and passwords, ensuring global
accessibility. This test validates that the system supports diverse
character encodings without security vulnerabilities.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment is standardized with a supported browser
    (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Edge) at 1920x1080 resolution with 100%
    zoom level
2.  Browser character encoding is set to UTF-8 to properly support
    Unicode characters
3.  System keyboard or input method editor supports Unicode and
    international character input
4.  The login page is accessible and fully loaded without JavaScript
    errors
5.  User is not currently authenticated and is viewing the login page
    for the first time in this session
6.  Test user accounts exist with Unicode or international characters in
    usernames and/or passwords for validation purposes
7.  Database and backend systems are configured to support Unicode
    character storage and comparison
8.  No browser extensions or plugins are interfering with character
    input or form encoding
Steps:
Navigate to the login page and verify that all form elements are
displayed correctly with proper character encoding
Expected Result:
Login page loads successfully with username and password fields ready to
accept input, and character encoding is set to UTF-8

Steps:
Enter a username containing Unicode characters from various scripts (for
example: Chinese characters '', Arabic characters ' ',
Cyrillic characters ' ', or emoji characters) in the
username field
Expected Result:
Unicode characters are displayed correctly in the username field without
garbling, encoding errors, or character corruption

Steps:
Enter a password containing Unicode characters from various
international character sets (for example: Greek characters '',
Hebrew characters '', or Japanese characters '')
Expected Result:
Unicode characters are accepted and displayed correctly in the password
field (typically shown as dots or asterisks for security) without
encoding errors

Steps:
Submit the login form with valid Unicode-based credentials that match a
test account in the system
Expected Result:
Form submission is processed successfully and authentication is
attempted with the Unicode credentials

Steps:
Verify in the browser network inspector that the submitted credentials
preserve the Unicode characters correctly in the request payload
Expected Result:
Submitted credentials in the request contain properly encoded Unicode
characters matching the input without character corruption or encoding
issues

Steps:
Confirm that the server-side validation correctly compares the submitted
Unicode credentials against stored values
Expected Result:
Authentication succeeds with correct Unicode credentials and fails
appropriately with incorrect Unicode credentials, demonstrating proper
character comparison

Steps:
Test with mixed Unicode and ASCII characters in both username and
password fields (for example: 'user123', 'pass@456')
Expected Result:
Mixed character sets are processed correctly without encoding conflicts
or validation errors

Steps:
Verify that special Unicode characters and combining diacritical marks
are handled correctly (for example: accented characters like 'caf',
'nave', or combining marks)
Expected Result:
Combining characters and diacritical marks are properly stored and
compared, allowing successful authentication with these complex Unicode
sequences

Steps:
Test Unicode characters at the boundaries of input field length limits
to ensure no truncation issues occur
Expected Result:
Unicode characters at or near maximum length limits are processed
correctly without unexpected truncation or character loss

Title: Authentication with Special Characters in Valid Credentials
Description:
Verifies that the authentication system correctly processes usernames
and passwords containing special characters, numbers, and symbols when
they are part of valid credentials. This ensures the system supports
diverse character sets in authentication data.
Preconditions:
1.  User has a valid registered account with username/email containing
    special characters (e.g., 'user.name+tag@example.com' or
    'user_name')
2.  User's password contains special characters, numbers, and symbols
    (e.g., 'P@ssw0rd!#123')
3.  Account is in active status and not locked or suspended
4.  Browser is set to a supported version (Chrome, Firefox, Safari,
    Edge)
5.  Browser resolution is set to 1920x1080 with 100% zoom level
6.  Cookies are enabled in the browser
7.  Stable and active internet connection is available
8.  No interfering browser extensions are present
9.  Login page is accessible and fully loaded
10. Browser character encoding is set to UTF-8 or supported encoding
Steps: Navigate to the login page
Expected Result:
Login page is fully loaded with email/username field, password field,
and login button visible

Steps:
Enter the username/email containing special characters (e.g.,
'user.name+tag@example.com')
Expected Result:
Username/email with special characters is entered correctly in the input
field

Steps:
Enter the password containing special characters, numbers, and symbols
(e.g., 'P@ssw0rd!#123')
Expected Result:
Password with special characters is entered in the password field
(displayed as masked characters)

Steps: Click the 'Login' or 'Submit' button
Expected Result:
Login request is submitted to the server with special characters
properly encoded

Steps: Wait for server to process the authentication with special characters
Expected Result:
Server properly decodes and validates the username/email and password
containing special characters

Steps: Observe authentication result
Expected Result:
Authentication is successful; user with special characters in
credentials is authenticated

Steps: Verify user is redirected to authenticated area
Expected Result:
User is successfully logged in and redirected to the authenticated
dashboard/home page

Title: Appropriate HTTP Status Codes for Authentication Failures
Description:
Tests that authentication failures return appropriate HTTP status codes
(such as 401 Unauthorized) without providing additional information that
could aid attackers. This ensures that HTTP responses maintain security
while following standard protocols.
Preconditions:
1.  System is deployed and accessible via HTTPS protocol
2.  A valid user account exists in the system with known credentials
    (username: testuser@example.com, password: TestPassword123)
3.  A test account or invalid credentials are prepared
    (invalid_user@example.com, WrongPassword123)
4.  HTTP client/tool is configured to capture and inspect response
    headers and status codes (e.g., Postman, curl, browser developer
    tools)
5.  Network connectivity is stable and active
6.  No account lockout is currently active on test accounts
7.  Application backend is running and authentication service is
    operational
8.  TLS/SSL certificate is valid and properly configured
Steps:
Attempt to authenticate with a valid username/email but incorrect
password
Expected Result:
System returns HTTP 401 (Unauthorized) status code in response header
without revealing whether the username/email exists in the system

Steps: Examine the HTTP response body for the authentication failure
Expected Result:
Response body contains a generic error message such as 'Invalid
credentials' or 'Authentication failed' without disclosing specific
information about whether the username or password was incorrect

Steps:
Attempt to authenticate with a non-existent username/email and any
password
Expected Result:
System returns HTTP 401 (Unauthorized) status code consistent with
invalid credentials scenario, not revealing that the username/email does
not exist

Steps: Examine the HTTP response body for the non-existent user attempt
Expected Result:
Response body displays the same generic error message as step 2,
maintaining security by not differentiating between invalid username and
invalid password

Steps:
Attempt authentication with empty username/email field and a password
value
Expected Result:
System returns HTTP 400 (Bad Request) status code indicating invalid
input format, with error message stating 'Username/email is required' or
similar validation message

Steps: Attempt authentication with username/email and empty password field
Expected Result:
System returns HTTP 400 (Bad Request) status code with error message
stating 'Password is required' or similar validation message

Steps:
Attempt authentication with both username/email and password fields
empty
Expected Result:
System returns HTTP 400 (Bad Request) status code with error message
indicating required fields are missing

Steps:
Verify that all error responses are transmitted over HTTPS with secure
headers (no plaintext transmission)
Expected Result:
HTTP response headers include security headers such as
'Strict-Transport-Security', 'Content-Security-Policy', and
'X-Content-Type-Options' to ensure secure transmission

Steps:
Inspect server logs and application logs for sensitive information
leakage
Expected Result:
Logs do not contain plaintext passwords, and authentication failures are
logged without exposing credential details or internal system
information that could aid attackers

Steps:
Verify response time consistency between successful and failed
authentication attempts
Expected Result:
Response times for failed authentication attempts are similar to
successful attempts (within acceptable variance), preventing
timing-based attacks that could reveal whether username exists

Title: Consistent Response Time for Valid and Invalid Credentials
Description:
Tests that the system maintains consistent response times for both valid
and invalid login attempts to prevent timing attacks that could reveal
information about credential validity. This ensures that response timing
cannot be used to determine if usernames exist in the system.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment standardized: supported browser (Chrome,
    Firefox, Safari, or Edge) with desktop resolution of 1920x1080, 100%
    zoom level, stable and active internet connection
2.  Application login page is accessible and fully loaded
3.  System clock is synchronized across client and server to enable
    accurate timing measurement
4.  Timing measurement tools/network profiler are ready to capture
    response times (e.g., Chrome DevTools Network tab, or automated
    timing instrumentation in test framework)
5.  Database connection is functioning normally without artificial
    delays
6.  No interfering browser extensions, JavaScript errors, or network
    throttling is enabled
7.  Server is operating under normal load conditions (not under stress
    or maintenance)
8.  Valid user account credentials are available for testing valid login
    attempt
9.  Known invalid username/email and password combinations are prepared
    for testing invalid login attempts
Steps: Navigate to the application login page and allow it to fully load
Expected Result:
Login page is displayed with username/email input field, password input
field, and login button visible

Steps:
Open browser developer tools (F12 or right-click > Inspect >
Network tab) to enable network monitoring and timing measurement
Expected Result:
Network tab is open and ready to capture HTTP requests and their
response times

Steps:
Enter a valid username/email and valid password in the respective login
fields
Expected Result:
Username/email field contains the valid credential value, password field
contains the valid password value

Steps:
Click the login button and immediately note the request initiation time
from network monitoring
Expected Result:
Login request is sent to the server; network tab shows the outgoing POST
request with timestamp

Steps:
Measure and record the complete response time for the valid login
attempt (from request initiation to response received), including the
time for server processing and response transmission
Expected Result:
Valid login response time is recorded (example: 450-550ms for processing
and network transmission combined)

Steps:
Verify that the login is successful and user is redirected to the
authenticated dashboard/home page
Expected Result:
User is successfully authenticated and redirected to the authenticated
area; session token/cookie is created

Steps:
Clear the session by logging out or clearing browser cookies/session
storage to return to unauthenticated state
Expected Result:
Session is cleared; user is returned to login page or unauthenticated
state; network tab is still open

Steps:
Enter an invalid username/email (example: 'nonexistentuser@example.com')
and an invalid password in the login fields
Expected Result:
Username/email field contains the invalid credential value, password
field contains an invalid password value

Steps:
Click the login button and immediately note the request initiation time
from network monitoring
Expected Result:
Login request with invalid credentials is sent to the server; network
tab shows the outgoing POST request with timestamp

Steps:
Measure and record the complete response time for the invalid login
attempt (from request initiation to response received), including the
time for server processing and response transmission
Expected Result:
Invalid login response time is recorded (example: 450-550ms for
processing and network transmission combined)

Steps:
Verify that the login is rejected and an appropriate error message is
displayed to the user without revealing whether the username exists or
if the password is incorrect
Expected Result:
Error message is displayed (example: 'Invalid username or password' or
similar generic message); user remains on login page; no session is
created

Steps:
Compare the recorded response times between valid and invalid login
attempts to determine the time difference
Expected Result:
Response time difference is calculated; difference should be
minimal/negligible (example: less than 100ms variance) to prevent
timing-based attacks

Steps:
Repeat the test at least 3 times with different valid and invalid
credential combinations to ensure consistency of response times across
multiple attempts
Expected Result:
Multiple response time measurements are recorded for both valid and
invalid attempts; all measurements show consistent timing patterns with
minimal variance between valid and invalid attempts

Steps:
Analyze all recorded response times to confirm that no statistically
significant timing difference exists between valid and invalid login
attempts that could reveal credential validity
Expected Result:
Response time analysis confirms that valid and invalid login attempts
have consistent response times within acceptable variance threshold
(example: 450-550ms for both), preventing timing-based information
disclosure

Title: Verify cart counter increments from zero to one on first Add to Cart click
Description:
This test validates that when a user clicks the 'Add to Cart' button for
the first time on a product, the cart counter badge displays '1'
immediately without requiring a page reload. This is critical for
establishing the initial cart state and ensuring users receive immediate
visual feedback that their action was successful.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser environment is standardized using a supported browser
    (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Edge) at desktop resolution 1920x1080
    with 100% zoom level.
2.  Stable and active internet connection is available.
3.  No JavaScript errors are present in the browser console.
4.  No interfering browser extensions or developer tools are active.
5.  The product page or product listing page is fully loaded without any
    rendering errors.
6.  The cart is empty (cart counter displays '0' or is not visible).
7.  Browser storage (localStorage/sessionStorage) is cleared or reset to
    ensure a clean initial state.
8.  At least one product with an 'Add to Cart' button is available and
    visible on the current page.
Steps: Load the product page or product listing page in the supported browser.
Expected Result:
The page loads completely without JavaScript errors. The cart counter
badge is visible in the header/navigation area and displays '0' or no
count indicator, indicating the cart is empty.

Steps: Locate the 'Add to Cart' button for a product.
Expected Result:
The 'Add to Cart' button is visible and accessible on the product card
or product detail page. The button is in an enabled state (clickable).

Steps: Click the 'Add to Cart' button for the first time.
Expected Result:
The cart counter badge updates immediately and displays '1' without
requiring a page refresh. The visual update occurs instantly, providing
immediate feedback to the user.

Steps: Verify the cart counter value displayed in the UI.
Expected Result:
The cart counter badge clearly shows the numeral '1' in the correct
position (consistent visual styling, proper alignment, no leading zeros,
correct font formatting).

Steps:
Open browser developer tools and check the browser storage (localStorage
or sessionStorage).
Expected Result:
The cart data is persisted in browser storage with the value of '1' item
in the cart. The stored cart count matches the displayed counter on the
UI.

Title: Verify cart counter increments from existing count on subsequent Add to Cart click
Description:
This test ensures that when a cart already contains items and a user
clicks 'Add to Cart' on any product, the counter increases by exactly 1
from the current count. This validates the increment logic works
correctly regardless of the starting cart state and maintains accurate
counting throughout the user session.
Preconditions:
1.  Web application is fully loaded with no JavaScript errors
2.  Browser is a supported type (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Edge)
3.  Desktop resolution is set to 1920x1080 at 100% zoom level
4.  Stable and active internet connection is available
5.  No interfering browser extensions or tools are active
6.  User has navigated to the product catalog/shopping page
7.  At least one product is available to add to cart
8.  Cart already contains items (e.g., cart counter currently displays a
    value greater than 0)
9.  Browser storage (localStorage or sessionStorage) is accessible and
    functional
Steps:
Open the product catalog or shopping page and verify that the cart
counter badge is visible and displays the current cart count (e.g.,
counter shows 2 items)
Expected Result:
Cart counter is clearly visible and displays the existing count
accurately

Steps: Identify and click the 'Add to Cart' button on any available product
Expected Result:
'Add to Cart' button is successfully clicked with no errors or UI
freezing

Steps: Observe the cart counter badge immediately after clicking 'Add to Cart'
Expected Result:
Cart counter increments by exactly 1 from the previous value (e.g., from
2 to 3 items)

Steps:
Verify that the counter displays the new incremented value without any
delay
Expected Result:
The counter shows the correct incremented value in real-time without
page reload

Steps: Repeat the process by clicking 'Add to Cart' on a different product
Expected Result:
Cart counter increments by 1 again from the current count (e.g., from 3
to 4 items)

Steps:
Confirm that the counter value increases consistently by 1 with each
subsequent add to cart action
Expected Result:
The increment logic works correctly regardless of the starting cart
state, maintaining accurate counting

Title: Verify cart counter updates immediately without page reload after Add to Cart click
Description:
This test confirms that the cart counter badge updates in real-time
immediately after clicking 'Add to Cart' without requiring any page
refresh or reload. This is essential for providing instant user feedback
and maintaining a smooth user experience during shopping activities.
Preconditions:
1.  Web application is fully loaded with no JavaScript errors
2.  Browser is a supported type (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Edge)
3.  Desktop resolution is set to 1920x1080 at 100% zoom level
4.  Stable and active internet connection is available
5.  No interfering browser extensions or tools are active
6.  User is on the product catalog or shopping page
7.  Cart counter badge is visible and clearly identifiable on the page
8.  At least one product with an 'Add to Cart' button is available
9.  No page navigation or automatic page refresh is occurring
Steps:
Observe the current cart counter value displayed on the page (e.g.,
counter shows 0, 1, or any existing value)
Expected Result: Cart counter badge is visible and the current count is clearly displayed

Steps:
Locate the 'Add to Cart' button on a product and click it without
navigating away or refreshing the page
Expected Result: 'Add to Cart' button responds to click action immediately

Steps:
Monitor the cart counter badge for visual updates immediately after the
click, without any page reload or refresh
Expected Result:
Cart counter updates in real-time to the new value (incremented by 1)
without any page reload or refresh requirement

Steps: Verify that the update occurs instantly with no noticeable lag or delay
Expected Result:
Counter update is instantaneous and provides immediate feedback to the
user

Steps:
Confirm that the page remains on the same location and all page content
persists without reload
Expected Result:
Page state is unchanged, and only the cart counter is updated without
affecting page navigation or content display

Steps: Click 'Add to Cart' again on another product and verify real-time update
Expected Result:
Cart counter updates immediately again in real-time without page reload,
demonstrating consistent real-time update behavior

Title: Verify cart counter displays correct numerical value after single Add to Cart action
Description:
This test validates that the cart counter badge shows the exact correct
number after a single 'Add to Cart' click, ensuring no mathematical
errors, display formatting issues, or incorrect value representation
occur. This is fundamental for maintaining user trust in the cart
functionality.
Preconditions:
1.  Web application is fully loaded with no JavaScript errors
2.  Browser is a supported type (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Edge)
3.  Desktop resolution is set to 1920x1080 at 100% zoom level
4.  Stable and active internet connection is available
5.  No interfering browser extensions or tools are active
6.  User is on the product catalog or shopping page
7.  Cart counter badge is visible and displayed prominently
8.  At least one product with an 'Add to Cart' button is available
9.  Cart is initially empty (counter displays 0) or contains items
    (counter displays the current count)
Steps:
Note the initial cart counter value before performing any action (e.g.,
counter shows 0)
Expected Result: Initial cart count is recorded and clearly visible

Steps: Click the 'Add to Cart' button on a selected product
Expected Result: 'Add to Cart' button is clicked successfully without errors

Steps: Observe the cart counter badge immediately after the click
Expected Result: Cart counter updates to display the new value

Steps:
Verify that the displayed counter value is mathematically correct
(initial count + 1)
Expected Result:
Counter shows the exact correct numerical value with no mathematical
errors (e.g., if initial was 0, counter now shows 1)

Steps:
Confirm that the counter value is properly formatted with no leading
zeros, incorrect decimal points, or formatting anomalies
Expected Result:
Counter displays the number in standard integer format without any
formatting issues

Steps:
Validate that the displayed value matches the actual cart item count
without discrepancies
Expected Result:
The counter accurately represents the number of items in the cart with
no mismatches or display inconsistencies

Title: Verify cart counter remains consistent when navigating from product page to category page
Description:
This test validates that when a user adds items to cart on a product
page and then navigates to a category page, the cart counter displays
the same count without resetting or losing data. This is critical for
maintaining cart state consistency across different page types during a
single browsing session.
Preconditions:
1.  Browser is set to a supported browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or
    Edge) at desktop resolution 1920x1080 with 100% zoom
2.  Stable, active internet connection is available
3.  No JavaScript errors are present in the browser console
4.  No interfering browser extensions are active
5.  User is on a product page with an 'Add to Cart' button visible
6.  The product page is fully loaded without any loading indicators
7.  Cart counter badge is visible and currently displays '0' or empty
    state
8.  Browser storage (localStorage) is enabled and functional
Steps:
Click the 'Add to Cart' button on the product page for a product (e.g.,
'Sample Product 1')
Expected Result:
Cart counter badge increments to '1' in real-time without page reload.
The counter is visually updated and remains visible at the top of the
page

Steps:
Navigate to a category page (e.g., 'Men' category) by clicking a
category link or using the navigation menu
Expected Result:
Page transitions to the category page and fully loads. Cart counter
badge remains visible and displays '1', matching the count from the
product page

Steps:
Verify the cart counter value is displayed correctly on the category
page
Expected Result:
Cart counter shows '1' consistently. No data loss or reset occurs. The
counter value matches the previous state from the product page

Steps:
Add another product to cart from the category page (click 'Add to Cart'
on any visible product)
Expected Result:
Cart counter increments to '2'. The updated count is displayed
immediately without page refresh

Steps: Navigate back to the product page using browser navigation or menu
Expected Result:
Cart counter remains at '2' on the product page. Cart state is
maintained across page navigation
